Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Comment: They should not swear during the hunting.

Feature: Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Comment: see above example in 9.7

Feature: Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Are there ritual songs?
Comment: no example given

Feature: Are there ritual dances?
Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Do women and men dance together?
Comment: There are mixed dances, but mostly it is the men who dance. Namang Hedong: for men mostly.

Feature: Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment: There is a ceremony only for men, called Tutu Adat, to tell traditional stories. The women cook and serve food.

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: There are two more rituals, called Jawa Letu' and Jawa Buka. Jawa Letu' is to close the planting period. During the ceremony there should not be any sound of a party. Jawa Buka is the opening of the new planting period. There are many rituals and music. Before they plant corn, they have a ceremony called Hika Toba. Through this ceremony they open one garden together, the garden of the tuan tanah (Nika Teun), in which they work together for one day. The ceremony involves cutting an animal (e.g. a goat or pig) and cook it and eat it together with ketupat (rice in coconut leaves). The next day they start to work in their own gardens.

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: From Kroko Puken (east) and Sina Java (=Chinese people from Java) Malaka (Sumatra).

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Comment: see above; also recording of traditional village where the man offers food and drink to the spirits of the ancestors.

Feature: Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: Nuba Nara, and in front of the rumah adat in the old village; and also in every garden.

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Comment: But there is another clan Hayon, which has a story that the Ikan Kro'o helped them and therefore they are forbidden to eat it. Elephants do not play a mythical role here, it's just their tanduk that is kept as pusaka or belis.

Feature: Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: Each clan has their own history. But there is a general origin story. Originally the people living here were Demo-Paji. Paji was here first and then Demo, they merged as a society. Then they found Gesti Tuli who appeared from the earth. The story is called Beto Lali Tana Haka. There is a baby named Gesti Tuli that was found because an eagle was flying around screaming and the people went to look for the baby in the forest. They assumed the baby was born from the ground, they took it with them and adopted it into their clan. But Gesti Tuli fought the Demo-Paji and they lost and left. Gesti Tuli became the ancestor of Keton and Kelen clans.

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Comment: Four leaders, one from each of the 4 important clans. They have their own task in traditional rituals.

Feature: Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: arak for rituals; (tuak just to drink), sirih pinang, tobacco. Traditional they make 'obat' for plants, called Habu Maa 'bathe sawah'. They spray it on the plants in the garden and leave the garden for 3 days.

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment: Called Hering Araa, each garden has it.

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: The ritual is called Wua' Lodo 'Ana' 'give name child'. 4 days and 3 nights after the birth, mother and child come outside the house. Everyone is called to eat sirih pinang, the mother serves. Then they also give the baby a name, and announce it to the people.

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: The ritual is called Hebo'. Four days after the burial the family of mother's brother come and have a party. On the table they put a piece of ivory, and the family discusses its price. After they agree on the price they cut chickens and drink tuak. This is makan belis. This ritual only applies with old man that are already grandfather. The family of the mother brings clothes/goods, the family of the father brings ivory.(Unclear !???)

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: Habu Nuba 'bathe stone'. There is one clan that has the task to do this ritual. They must go to Nuba Nara, the place where they do the rituals, and they need to cut a pig or goat and then they go home and call out: the rain is coming, and then the rain will come.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Is there traditional pottery?
Are there moko?
Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: Bamboo flute, drum, gong, ukelele.

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Comment: Not special for this village.

Feature: Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Comment: Women and men have tattoo, it can be put anywhere on the body. It is made of body paint named Kanire'eng which is made of burned coal and sugar of tuak, which is applied with a duri. Tattoos can be put everywhere. Men have figures of cecak, spider, scorpion; women usually have flowers. It used to make you dat je niet geraakt of gekwetst kan worden als iemand je snijdt of slaat.

Feature: Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: Called Doro Ipə. With stones as in the other places. Nowadays it is no longer done.

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Comment: Half long hair for men with a tail on the back of the head. Women have long hair called Bewuge', hair bound in a knot with a pin in it, which is called Nugi = duri landak =egel.

Feature: Traditional piercings?
Comment: Only in ears.

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: Head piece is made of lontar leaf with chicken feathers, as many as they want. The head piece of women is closed on the top, the men's is open with chicken feathers on it.

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: Bracelet and necklace and earrings. Bracelet and necklace of ivory, earrings not.

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: Sarong, kain and headpiece.

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: north: rae = mountain, south: lau = sea, west: lara halu= sun set, east: lara gere = sun rise. So the directional system is directed towards the mountain/sea, and not absolute.

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Comment: If a lontar tree is tall with a single fruit stick its called Mara Laki, a male tree. If a lontar tree is not so tall but has many fruits sticks hanging down its called Mara Roneng, a female tree.

Feature: Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Lamaholot

Feature: Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: Mostly from Java, Sumatra, Kalimantan, but also from other villages

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: The husband/wife that comes from outside and lives in Lewoingu will learn Lamaholot.

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: See previous

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: Indonesian

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: When consultant was still young they used to hunt for wild pigs, deer, using bow and arrow, spear, with a dog.

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: They search for fish when the tide is low, beach is 2 km from village. They spear fish and also use poison from root of Pohon Tuba that they put into a hole in the reef and then the fish comes out.

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: pig, goat, chicken, dogs (no horses, cows, buffalo)

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: Gardens are in the village and closeby, as well as far from the village borders (> 10 km). Wet rice is in the valley.

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Major crops?
Comment: Wet rice, corn, millet, mente, kemiri, cacao, banana, two types of spices (lada)

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: The clans include: Manuk, Tukan, Kewen, Koten, Kelen, Maran, Uri, Sapa Hera, Badung.

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: Clans are the same as moieties, e.g. in the naming: Bernardus Boli Manuk: Bernardus = catholic name, Boli = name of ancestor or hero, Manuk = clan / moietie name.

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: Each village has its own traditional house. Its called Lango Belen, 'house big'. To keep the the sacred objects of the village, e.g. ivory.

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: Four clans are higher than the others, because they were the first to settle on the land. They are: Koton, Kelen, Marang, Huri. There are many more clans. Each clan has its own traditional task in ceremonies, e.g. one clan has the task to hold the animal's head, the other to hold the rope, the other to hold the tail, and one to cut the neck/artery.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Comment: Sons get equal share, daughters get nothing.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: The house goes to the eldest son.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: The Raja of Larantuka was originally the owner of all the land. This kingdom was in place before the colonial times. In the village, the land is owned by the four important clans, who were politically under the king of Larantuka.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: Sawah/field/garden: divided between the sons. Rumah adat (if father is kepala suku): the title and the house goes to the eldest son. Ivory goes to eldest son. Kain tenun divided between sons and daughters (daughters optional). In general the youngest son gets the least and daughters do not inherit.

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Comment: Women are excluded, they do not even get clothes from their parents (goes to the clan of the bride's father.) They become part of the clan of their husband. That clan receives the belis.

Feature: Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: People from outside can buy land and build a house. No restrictions.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: Before it was 30+ for men, because they had to have a supply from the gardens (gudang makanan) and it was 20+ for women because they had to know how to weave and have a supply of clothes (gudang pakaian)

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: There is a marriage exchange rule called Tika telo (tungku three). Three clans are Tukan, Kelen and Manu. The men from Kelen marry girls from Manu, the men from Manu marry girls from Tukan and the men from Tukan marry girls from Kelen. It is forbidden to marry girls in the opposite direction.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: Rengki: a service from the bride's family to feed a spoonful of rice to the couple. It is done by the bride's sister and brother.

Feature: Is there bride service?
Comment: There is no bride service but if belis is not yet paid, it is utang adat, and the debt will remain and be inherited by the children. You can also repay it by providing a girl for another marriage.

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: Optional.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Comment: As long as they don't have a house, they stay with their parents (husband or wife). When they have a house, they can move to stay wherever they want.

Feature: Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
Comment: They must marry outside the clan, following the 3 tungku principle. (To marry mother's brother's child is no longer applied today.)

Feature: If mother dies, who raises the children?
Comment: Children are part of father's clan.
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Comment: It is a right and an obligation that a man marries the daughter of the brother of his mother. If he does not do this, he has to pay a fine, as belis.

Feature: Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Comment: It is not typical, but it is possible, if it follows the 3 tungku principle (see above)

Feature: Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Comment: There are no locality restrictions. The 3 tungku principle must be applied.

Feature: Was polygamy permitted
Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: Ivory. It's called weling əlang.

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: Kain, clothes. It called Ohe.It's worth half of the belis.

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: It used to be separated. There are four different groups: Bele, Roki, Ketepu, Koke. Each village has 5-6 families per group, and the villages are separated by a few hundred meters and woods.

Feature: Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Comment: Not centred on related men or women.

Feature: Mean size of local communities?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Comment: Villages are traditionally in the mountains but not on hilltops.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Comment: They only have a house at the beach, to work on salt production from sea water.

Feature: Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: Village square, called bale desa now. Traditional house is called Korke, it is located in the old village.

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Floor level of traditional houses?
Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Comment: It's rectangular, two low and long slopes, two small ones.

Feature: Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Comment: Just bale bale where ivory is kept (see pictures). There are 8 poles: symbols for the 4 important suku facing their partner clans (maybe the next 4 clans that arrived); now the 8 poles symbolize the inclusion of all the clans into one unit.

Feature: Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: Traditional leaders come from the 4 important clans. Each of them has their own leader.

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Comment: If someone is capable and ready to be a leader, he can be selected. But he has to be a member of one of the 4 leading clans.

Feature: Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: Around 1950's there was a war Perang Tanding, between kampong Leworo'ok and Lewokluok about borders.

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: All people live in the mountains.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Are there men’s houses
Comment: In the past, there were bevak, places where young men could hang out.

Feature: Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: The king is from Larantuka, but each village has a Kakang = the head of the village, who reports to the king.

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: Earlier there were people without parents who were adopted into families as 'slaves' but not anymore. Non-hereditary.

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Comment: Raja Usi=Raja Larantuka, a local ruler.

Feature: Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: Nowadays there are corporations of farmers who keep the harvest of all the farmers in order to control the market price.

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: Nowadays name is given after they are born and then baptized. The father's party gives the nameif the belis has been paid. If not, then the mother's party gives the name.
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Comment: The clan name.

Feature: Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: Yes if the belis is paid.

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Comment: If the father has not paid the belis yet.

Feature: Are there name taboos?
Comment: The name of a mad person or someone with a bad reputation cannot be used anymore.

Feature: Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment: Koda Kiring Ama Bapa (koda = word, message; ama bapa = from the ancestors).

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: Rase gahang, Ata gahang = new person, other person
